newsitem.title: USA: Unimed acquires drug to treat anemias.
newsitem.headline: Unimed acquires drug to treat anemias.

text.p: Unimed Pharmaceuticals Inc said Tuesday it has acquired from Syntex all rights to market Oxymetholone, a drug used to treat anemias, in the U.S., Canada and Mexico.
Anemias are caused by deficient red blood cell production.
Oxymetholone has been sold under the trade name Anadrol in the U.S. and as Anapolon in Canada and Mexico.
Unimed's launch of Anadrol in the U.S. is scheduled for late in the fourth quarter of this year.

Under terms of the agreement, Unimed said it will pay to Syntex a licensing fee, in three installments, and a royalty on net product sales. Syntex will provide Unimed with an initial supply of finished tablets and will transfer all know-how regarding the product to Unimed. Unimed will own the active registrations for oxymetholone in the U.S., Canada and Mexico.
Unimed said the acquisition of the drug is consistent with its strategy to develop and market products for niche pharmaceutical markets such as hematology.
Syntex was acquired by Roche Holding Ltd in 1994.
